author: doducduy96
body:
I buy VOO every month with 40% of my income. Whenever I feel anxious about my position, I take a deep breath, a day off and go for a walk/drive around town. When I walkout of the door, a AMZN package I ordered 18 hours ago had already been here, neat. Then I take out my AAPL phone and go to GOOGL to look for a place to eat/chill, just got my PFE vaccine last month so I’m good to go. Hoping into my trust worthy F F150 and starting to drive, I notice that hmmm I have been seeing a lot of TSLA cars around, maybe it’ll be my next car? I’m daydreaming. The drive is 5 miles, I wonder why the HDs, COSTs, WMTs, TGTs parking are always packed like that, even tho it’s only Wednesday, 
Hmmm guess I’ll skip groceries today. I feel lazy. Sitting at the restaurant’s outdoor patio, I enjoy my brunch with a glass of wine, my eyes start wandering around. What a beautiful day, the birds, the air, the people. Maybe it’s enough wine for the day, I go in to grab a soft drink. 8 out of 10 drinks on the fountain machine are KO products. Lots people around me are working on their AAPL and MSFT laptops. They are so thin yet very powerful. As a tech geek I know they are powered by INTC and AMD CPUs, and the heavy stuffs are done with NVIDIA GPUs. Gosh people are so productive nowadays! It’s time to leave, I lay my JPM V card to the tray, 5x points for dining baby! 5 mins later I’m on my way. Shit, I’m almost out of gas, pulling into a CVX gas station, tap my BAC MA card because I’ll get 3% cash back on Gas. Damn there’s a line wrapping around that MCD and SBUX drive thru, the food is unhealthy but well business is still booming I guess. 
Getting back into my home, I suddenly remember tomorrow is Oct 1st. I have T, VZ, NFLX bills to pay. 
Damn, I observed a lot from my lazy day today. I wonder what my life would be without all of the conveniences I saw today. 
I log into my Fidelity account and buy 4 more VOO shares. 
Feeling good.

author: tdreampo
body:
So as a person that’s been an investor for decades AND I have worked in the tech industry for decades, I personally have sold all my Intel stock. I held Intel for about fifteen years but I’m now very convinced that their glory days are behind them. They certainly will be a billion dollar company for decades to come but they are just far too behind the next big race. Here is why. 

The actual architecture and nature of the cpu race has changed. For years it was all about raw performance, we saw this with x86 architecture (which is intels bread and butter) we have seen this for 30 years, higher clock speeds, more cores. But two major shifts happened in the industry that Intel just isn’t prepared for. One is the rise of mobile devices led by the iPhone with android soon to follow. Power consumption became the driving metric for better battery life. Most mobile phones use a cpu architecture called“ARM” vs Intels x86 architecture that powers most windows devices. ARM CPU’s use considerably less power then their x86 counterparts and now that the worlds primary computer is their phone, arm has considerable market share. The next thing that happened was ARM CPU’s became incredibly powerful and could rival (and sometimes just destroy) X86 CPU’s in performance while consuming less power. The industry term now is “performance per watt” This is why Apple is switching out their entire product line to ARM even on Mac’s which over the last decade or so ran Intel CPU’s. 

Another tech shift is cloud computing with the rise of AWS, Azure and Google cloud. Electric costs are out of control for big data centers so these guys are turning to ARM CPU’s for server side work as well. This is a MASSIVE shift in the industry that no one knows about except people that work in the industry. So Intel is being directly assaulted on both the server side and the mobile side in a war that they were WAY late to the party on. I don’t see them recovering easily from this shift. 

Now of course none of this happens over night and it will probably take a decade but their hay-days are behind them. Then you look at what AMD is doing and they are actually making decent products after all these years. So even on Intels home turf they have a fierce competitor. Hope that helps.

author: Bamstradamus
body:
DDR5 news might provide a pop, but they would still have to sell the memory.  I have said it over and over on CRSR posts, this chip shortage is not ending any time soon, the vast majority of people are still waiting on GPU's to upgrade anything, especially since at higher resolutions the bottleneck moves from the CPU to the GPU, you can run 4k60 on a first gen Ryzen as long as you have a GPU capable of outputting the frames.

Add to that historically the first set of chips on a new DDR is typically slower then the previous gens top tier, the fact all RAM is essentially the same since their are only 3 major manufacturers and everyone just repackages those chips, GSkill probably outbidding everyone else for "the good chip" at the start again *seriously did any of you even build a Ryzen system, Corsair had like 4 compatible sku's for the entire 300 series chipsets life, Gskill got all the B-die*
and the fact we don't have any real world specs to work with yet I don't know anyone chomping at the bit for the DDR5 release.

I can see the news drop leading to a pop, I do not see DDR5 sales making an actual contribution to value until the NEXT set of chipsets come from AMD/Intel.

author: brutl_duess
body:
This is an income play I've been doing consistently for 1% to 2% a week:

Yesterday sold CSP on US Steel(x) Sept. 24th 25 Strike. Credit of .77

Then, immediately buy 24.5 long put for Sept. 17, debit of .33. 

Now I have net credit of .44, or 1.7%. For this entire week, I only "risk" .06. If the stock drops, the long put protects on the down side. If shares go up, yay!

On this Friday before close, I will roll both options out to the next expiry, the 24th for the long and Oct.1 for the CSP. If the stock is down, I keep the same strikes, doesn't matter that its in the money. If the stock is up, I'll roll the CSP to an ATM strike and the long at the same or one strike under the CSP. 

Essentially, I'm selling the time difference. I'm not vulnerable to huge drops because of the long put. Continue to keep rolling every Friday and collecting credits. You can find better premiums on more volatile issues, but I prefer names that I wouldn't mind owning long term anyway. I found a really nice setup in AMD that's paying about 1%. Hopefully this helps. Good luck.

author: UnstableCortex
body:
I don't quite understand why people compare valuation ratios with the industry average. Isn't it possible the entire sector is in a bubble? This is a genuine question. I would appreciate an answer.

GPU crypto mining is more likely to die out than to grow. As far as I know, no new crypto project uses Proof of Work. That leaves us with Bitcoin and its cousins. If Bitcoin succeeds, mining difficulty will ratchet up and GPUs will not even be considered for mining. If Bitcoin fails, no one will want to mine anyway. And already, most of network's hashing power comes from ASIC rigs, if I'm not mistaken.

For gaming, NVIDIA does have a pretty good moat in PC gaming, eventhough they have lost the consoles to AMD for now. And AMD is closing in. But, I think the bigger threat is a good game streaming service. If Google Stadia or a hypothetical Apple service becomes good, which I think is highly likely, they won't have any trouble catching a userbase, given their extensive ecosystem. While GeForce Now might be a good subscription model for NVIDIA, IMO it'll be difficult for it to compete against a service that comes with an entrenched ecosystem. While it is possible that NVIDIA chips power those game streaming services, it is also possible that they don't. With AMD closing in, and the larger trend of companies designing their own chips, no telling how that might go.

I welcome critical comments.

author: justbrain
body:
Dive further into price action. Plenty of information out there to help with that (books or youtube/google). Have an understanding how candles work. What they are, how to interpret them, how they can help you determine direction of a stock. 

Start your screen time learning/experience. Nothing beats actively watching stuff move and unfold right in front of you.

Stick to a few stocks. If you really want to be anal about it, just pick 1 stock. Preferably a NASDAQ stock, so take AMD for instance. Watch it every market open for say 30 minutes and see if you can't grasp how it tends to move right at open, 5 minutes into it, how much of a move it's capable of making. Some days it tends to open lower only to cancel out the direction and end day higher, some days it tends to run up for 7 minutes only to give back all its gains. There is a lot to learn from a stock's movement by simply watching it over and over.

Then, have some capital set aside, and start to trade very small (can't get smaller than 1 contract, but you can go as low as 1 share and continually increase it to more if you plan to trade its stock). I personally don't mess with stock for trading. I love options more.

author: Look_here_Listen_
body:
Well in their current state I wouldn’t say they are undervalued. They are going to have declining revenues and earnings for the foreseeable future. No reason to pay a premium on that. 

If you believe in the blue sky scenario, then yeah they are incredibly undervalued. I just don’t see them delivering on their roadmap without hiccups; they never get things out on time. 

They will continue to lose market share across all their CPU lines for the next 2-3 years minimum. AMD is just now eating away at their server market share which will be pretty disastrous for intel since they have great margins.

I think intel is an interesting turnaround play, but there still is downside risk.

AAPL AMD AMZN AVPT BARK CELH CRM CRWD DIS F GOOG MELI PINS PYPL SOFI UPST

This is my portfolio but I also have 20% split across three biotechs that I can't post in this subreddit. That's my high r/r, but I also don't feel like they're that risky because I know what I own.  

Read all the 10-K and 10-Q.  Listen to earnings calls and take notes.  Keep on top of national and world news. Look at options chains to get sentiment. Use Twitter for news and such. Learn how to read candlestick charts and spot reversals.  Don't panic sell. Don't listen to the noise online.

I broke $1.5m this morning.

author: LifeInAction
body: I started investing in 2017 and remember debating between making 25% of my total portfolio either Nvidia or AMD, I choose Nvidia, with AMD being an absolute sideways stock at that time, and while so happy to be up a ton, imagining what could've been if it was AMD. Thankfully grabbed SHOP, which also went parabolic. It was a fun year to invest, when things were so much significantly cheaper.

author: Codicus1212
body:
I just found an old investment notebook from 2017 that I used to keep track of all my invesents in (before I started buying dozens of options every week). 

I found a note to myself in it, reminding myself to buy $1000 worth of AMD if it dropped down to $7 again, but that it was overpriced at $10 at the moment.

Also included in this notebook were my thoughts on buying Microsoft (in the $80 range) but how it was risky at that price level. As well as how I should invest in lithium to capitalize on the EV market (that could have been a 300% play at least).

Of course I never did any of this. I just threw all of my money into Bitcorn and sold when it hit $2000. 

Can I get an F?

author: WilliamTheGamer
body: AMD is one of the least speculative and more proof tech stocks. They don't often rally without crystal clear good news, and even that sometimes causes it to drop because investors were expecting more. That being said, AMD is a solid long term hold, but I'd go 60DTE from earnings and buy ITM options. Or just buy shares. AMD is a very hard options play.
